awd_titl_txt: CAREER: PDE approaches to Physical Phenomena driven by Gravity and Diffusion
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is concerned with the investigation of physically important phenomena driven by gravity and diffusion, based on partial differential equations (PDE) approaches. In particular, such diverse phenomena as collapse of stars or generation of vortices at the interface between two fluids give rise to similar mathematical models. These model equations (Euler-Poisson, Navier-Stokes systems, Fokker-Planck equations, kinetic transport and Boltzmann equations) are widely used to describe the motion of compressible fluids and gases. They have rich applications in mathematical sciences and engineering and pose formidable mathematical challenges. This project aims to advance knowledge in this fundamental area of mathematics and to influence other domains of mathematics. Results will provide some evidence to other disciplines such as astrophysics, plasma physics, aerodynamics, and computational physics, chemistry, and biology, and may lead to scientific and technological advances. The research project will be integrated with educational and outreach activities such as student research projects, one-to-one mentoring activities, course development, summer schools for undergraduate and graduate students and interdisciplinary conferences. The project will strengthen the Applied Mathematics program at University of California-Riverside by means of integrated research, education and outreach activities. Through summer schools and conferences, it will be providing excellent learning opportunities for students with one of the goals being to broaden participation of underrepresented groups.

In particular, the following topics will be studied: (i) gravitational collapses of the Euler-Poisson system, the dynamics of rotating stars, relativity and radiation, (ii) Rayleigh-Taylor instability and the counterpart stability of two-fluid compressible Navier-Stokes system with or without surface tension, (iii) absorbing, elastically and inelastically reflecting boundary collisions for the kinetic Fokker-Planck equations, (iv) multi-scale dynamics from the kinetic transport and Boltzmann equations in the presence of boundary: theory and computation. The goal is to find a mathematical framework where these physical phenomena can be captured and to develop an appropriate mathematical theory by using PDE methods.

por.por_cntn:
The problems investigated by the PI under the scope of the award address physically important phenomena including gas expansion, gravitational collapses, stellar rotation, inelastic boundary collisions, and multi-scale dynamics. These physically motivated problems offer mathematical challenges and often novel ideas and tools are called for. Newly developed framework and methodologies could open up new lines of research and make an impact on other related areas. 

The Euler equations, first written by Euler in the eighteen century, consist of partial differential equations governing the dynamics of inviscid fluid or gas flow; they represent conservation of mass, momentum and energy with unknowns of the density, the velocity and the entropy of fluid or gas. Gas expansion into vacuum is an interesting physical phenomenon predicted by special solutions of the Euler equations. By exploiting the invariances of the system, the PI with collaborators has rigorously shown that the compressible Euler equations admit the stable expanding solutions for isentropic and non-isentropic flows in vacuum free boundary framework. Moreover, we have shown that even in the presence of gravity the stable expansion phenomenon can be demonstrated with well-chosen initial data. The methods developed for global existence of expanding solutions offer a new perturbative way of studying the free boundary problems. 

The gravitational Euler-Poisson system is a classical hydrodynamic model describing the motion of self-gravitating Newtonian stars. Two important physical phenomena associated with the system are stellar rotation and gravitational collapse. The PI with collaborator has constructed slowly rotating star solutions by developing a perturbative method around the Lane-Emden star solution, which provides a rigorous justification of the astrophysicists? asymptotic analysis in 1930s. On the other hand, the existence of collapsing solutions in a super critical regime has been conjected based on scaling argument and has been an outstanding open problem. The PI with collaborators has constructed infinite dimensional family of finite time collapsing solutions to the Euler-Poisson system whose leading order behavior is governed by the dust dynamics by using the rescaling due to super-criticality and flatness of the center of the background density, and this result gives rise to the first existence result of Newtonian gravitational collapse with finite mass and finite energy. 

The kinetic Fokker-Planck equation appears in different areas of science ranging from plasma physics, biological science to finance. Physically interesting problems are often accompanied by boundary conditions. Together with collaborators, the PI has investigated the dynamics of absorbing barrier under the Fokker-Planck equation by studying the detailed behavior of solutions near the singular set, and in multi-dimensional setting, in contrast to other kinetic equations without dissipation, we have obtained the existence and the regularity of solutions regardless of the geometry of the boundary. A further investigation was pursued in the presence of inelastic boundary collision, which could cause inelastic collision below a threshold. We have clarified the different dynamics observed in physics community by virtue of non-uniqueness of measure-valued solutions due to the presence of the singular set and possibly different behavior there. 

The hydrodynamic limit from the Boltzmann equation provides a passage between kinetic theory and fluid dynamics, and it has been of a great interest among mathematics community. Despite a lot of important progress, a rigorous theory in the presence of the boundary is still far from being complete. The PI with collaborator has derived the incompressible Euler equations with no penetration boundary condition from the Boltzmann equation with diffuse reflection boundary based on a multi-scale Hilbert expansion and the inviscid limit of the Navier-Stokes equations for large Reynold numbers with analytic data. The method could shed some light on other multi-scale limit problems. 

Results of this award have been disseminated through journal publications and various seminar and conference talks. Also, the award has provided an educational and training opportunity to mentor students. Two summer schools on mathematical fluids and related topics supported by the award were held at the University of Southern California in 2017 and 2019 and they provided an educational and networking opportunity for participants.
